head.title: A Place to View the Gems of Manhattan

Re ''Modern Architecture Has a Midlife Crisis'' (news article, May 15):
I am an Illinoisan who loves New York, lived there for a while and continues to enjoy visiting.

To me, the great difficulty for architecture in Manhattan is the lack of room for perspective on so many of the streets and avenues. Lincoln Center is a spot where the buildings are of good quality and work together, and where the site provides space for good views.

In far too few ground-level places can one see and enjoy (or criticize) architecture's contribution to the public environment. Lincoln Center is unquestionably a landmark, and its buildings shouldn't be tampered with much.
Around Manhattan, there are any number of huge and undistinguished steel boxes in cramped quarters that could be axed in the name of correcting Modernism's weaknesses.
Columbus Circle is another location where one can see the buildings well, and it therefore deserves and demands good buildings.
